author: sky.cactus
content: I don't believe there is any reasonable definition of "know" that makes this statement true: "You can know in advance what transactions people will want to submit."

author: sky.cactus
content: And if we cannot know what transactions people want to submit, we cannot know what the shape of the block will be, thus we cannot know what a person needs to sign over.

author: sky.cactus
content: We can ask for the canonical signature of "this" block, but we cannot ask for the canonical signature of the "next" block because we don't yet know what the next block is until *after* the chain has come to consensus on it.

author: sky.cactus
content: We want to target the punishment only at those who behave poorly, that way we can make the cost for them very high without giving them an obvious mechanism by which to hedge their position prior to attacking the system.

author: sky.cactus
content: If we just (for example) shutdown the whole chain when something went wrong (driving the price to zero), someone could short the coin and then trigger a shutdown and come out ahead.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think ideally, we would want slashed funds to be redistributed to those who were good actors so as to incentivize defecting and challenging.

author: sky.cactus
content: We can just burn the funds as a proxy though, and then potentially mint funds for good behavior (which is what Ethereum does).  I do still think there is value in giving slashed funds to other validators though as this incentivizes people more directly try to trick people into doing bad things and then backstab them.

author: sky.cactus
content: Of course, it also incentivizes people compromise other people's validators/validator keys.  I actually think this is a good thing for the overall health of the network though as it allows us to bleed out poorly secured validators without an active attack on the network.  Without this incentive, an attacker is only incentivized to compromise keys if they can manage an attack, so you have the problem where everything appears to be fine right up until it isn't.  You don't get any early warning signs or culling of the herd.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think there is significant value to be had in creating active incentives for people to compromise Coinbase, Kraken, etc. as it is much better that they fail ASAP (if they are going to fail) than waiting until an attacker has compromised 51% of them and *then* they show their hand.

author: sky.cactus
content: This strategy *tends* to not work well for systems that can be exit scammed.  However, in theory it *could* work if you can turn a guaranteed future value into nothing.  The problem is that "guaranteed future value" is complicated and it is usually easier to just slash people's today-money.

author: killari.

author: sky.cactus
content: Proof of Stake is a bit different from Augur in that we actually *want* a Keynesian Beauty Contest for Proof of Stake.  We really don't care which fork is most popular, we just need consensus on *one of them*.

author: sky.cactus
content: With Augur, we specifically are trying to avoid a KBC so it needs more complicated (and arguably less capital efficient) mechanisms.
